title: China Stocks Sink Despite Intervention Effort
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Tue, Jul 7, 2015, 14:31 BST - UK Markets close in 1 hr 59 mins China Stocks Sink Despite Intervention Effort By (c) Sky News 2015 | Sky News – 1 hour 30 minutes ago View Photo 

Chinese markets fell by as much as 5.05% on Tuesday, despite interventions from the Chinese government aimed at averting a stock market collapse. 
Emergency intervention measures introduced by the Chinese government over the weekend seem to be failing to stabilise the markets, in what analysts say is a make-or-break week for the Asian finance sector. 
The measures include supporting brokerages and fund managers to allow them to buy more stock using a direct line of liquidity from the Chinese central bank, and halting the release of all initial public offerings, or IPOs, for the “near future” to encourage traders to buy existing stock rather than new releases. 
Shanghai closed down 1.29%, or 48.79 points on Tuesday despite enjoying a boost following the announcement of the measures on Monday, and China’s second exchange in Shenzhen also slumped by 5.34%. 
Hong Kong finished 1.03% down, losing 260.97 points to end at 24975.31, extending losses of 3.18% from Monday. 
The mainland Chinese markets have plunged almost 30% in recent weeks after enjoying massive growth in the past 12-18 months. 
Previous attempts by China to arrest the slump - including an interest rate cut, relaxed rules on margin trading and proposals to let the state social security funds invest in equities - have so far failed, with analysts saying the new measures are unlikely to make a difference either. 
"The more resources authorities commit to propping up the stock market, the more they ratchet up the potential fall-out risks should the market continue to collapse," said Andrew Wood, an analyst at BMI Research. 
"This could give rise to a crisis of confidence in the authorities' ability to support both the stock market and the real economy."
